speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: SCENE II. London. The palace.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Enter KING EDWARD IV, GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, and LADY GREY

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Brother of Gloucester, at Saint Alban's field

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: This lady's husband, Sir Richard Grey, was slain,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: His lands then seized on by the conqueror:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Her suit is now to repossess those lands;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Which we in justice cannot well deny,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Because in quarrel of the house of York

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: The worthy gentleman did lose his life.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Your highness shall do well to grant her suit;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: It were dishonour to deny it her.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: It were no less; but yet I'll make a pause.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  Yea, is it so?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I see the lady hath a thing to grant,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Before the king will grant her humble suit.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  He knows the game: how true

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: he keeps the wind!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  Silence!

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Widow, we will consider of your suit;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And come some other time to know our mind.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Right gracious lord, I cannot brook delay:

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: May it please your highness to resolve me now;

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: And what your pleasure is, shall satisfy me.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  Ay, widow? then I'll warrant

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: you all your lands,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: An if what pleases him shall pleasure you.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Fight closer, or, good faith, you'll catch a blow.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  I fear her not, unless she

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: chance to fall.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE] God forbid that! for he'll

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: take vantages.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: How many children hast thou, widow? tell me.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  I think he means to beg a

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: child of her.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  Nay, whip me then: he'll rather

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: give her two.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Three, my most gracious lord.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  You shall have four, if you'll

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: be ruled by him.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: 'Twere pity they should lose their father's lands.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Be pitiful, dread lord, and grant it then.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Lords, give us leave: I'll try this widow's wit.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  Ay, good leave have you; for

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: you will have leave,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Till youth take leave and leave you to the crutch.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: GLOUCESTER and CLARENCE retire

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Now tell me, madam, do you love your children?

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Ay, full as dearly as I love myself.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And would you not do much to do them good?

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: To do them good, I would sustain some harm.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Then get your husband's lands, to do them good.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Therefore I came unto your majesty.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: I'll tell you how these lands are to be got.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: So shall you bind me to your highness' service.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: What service wilt thou do me, if I give them?

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: What you command, that rests in me to do.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: But you will take exceptions to my boon.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: No, gracious lord, except I cannot do it.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Ay, but thou canst do what I mean to ask.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Why, then I will do what your grace commands.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  He plies her hard; and much rain

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: wears the marble.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  As red as fire! nay, then

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: her wax must melt.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Why stops my lord, shall I not hear my task?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: An easy task; 'tis but to love a king.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: That's soon perform'd, because I am a subject.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Why, then, thy husband's lands I freely give thee.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: I take my leave with many thousand thanks.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  The match is made; she seals it

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: with a curtsy.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: But stay thee, 'tis the fruits of love I mean.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: The fruits of love I mean, my loving liege.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Ay, but, I fear me, in another sense.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: What love, think'st thou, I sue so much to get?

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: My love till death, my humble thanks, my prayers;

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: That love which virtue begs and virtue grants.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: No, by my troth, I did not mean such love.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Why, then you mean not as I thought you did.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: But now you partly may perceive my mind.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: My mind will never grant what I perceive

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Your highness aims at, if I aim aright.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: To tell thee plain, I aim to lie with thee.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: To tell you plain, I had rather lie in prison.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Why, then thou shalt not have thy husband's lands.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Why, then mine honesty shall be my dower;

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: For by that loss I will not purchase them.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Therein thou wrong'st thy children mightily.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Herein your highness wrongs both them and me.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: But, mighty lord, this merry inclination

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Accords not with the sadness of my suit:

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Please you dismiss me either with 'ay' or 'no.'

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Ay, if thou wilt say 'ay' to my request;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: No if thou dost say 'no' to my demand.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: Then, no, my lord. My suit is at an end.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  The widow likes him not, she

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: knits her brows.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  He is the bluntest wooer in

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Christendom.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: [Aside]  Her looks do argue her replete with modesty;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Her words do show her wit incomparable;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: All her perfections challenge sovereignty:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: One way or other, she is for a king;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And she shall be my love, or else my queen.--

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Say that King Edward take thee for his queen?

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: 'Tis better said than done, my gracious lord:

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: I am a subject fit to jest withal,

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: But far unfit to be a sovereign.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Sweet widow, by my state I swear to thee

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: I speak no more than what my soul intends;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And that is, to enjoy thee for my love.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: And that is more than I will yield unto:

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: I know I am too mean to be your queen,

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: And yet too good to be your concubine.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: You cavil, widow: I did mean, my queen.

speaker: LADY GREY
text_entry: 'Twill grieve your grace my sons should call you father.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: No more than when my daughters call thee mother.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Thou art a widow, and thou hast some children;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And, by God's mother, I, being but a bachelor,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Have other some: why, 'tis a happy thing

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: To be the father unto many sons.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Answer no more, for thou shalt be my queen.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside to CLARENCE]  The ghostly father now hath done

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: his shrift.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  When he was made a shriver,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: 'twas for shift.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Brothers, you muse what chat we two have had.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The widow likes it not, for she looks very sad.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: You'll think it strange if I should marry her.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: To whom, my lord?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Why, Clarence, to myself.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That would be ten days' wonder at the least.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: That's a day longer than a wonder lasts.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: By so much is the wonder in extremes.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Well, jest on, brothers: I can tell you both

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Her suit is granted for her husband's lands.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Enter a Nobleman

speaker: Nobleman
text_entry: My gracious lord, Henry your foe is taken,

speaker: Nobleman
text_entry: And brought your prisoner to your palace gate.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: See that he be convey'd unto the Tower:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And go we, brothers, to the man that took him,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: To question of his apprehension.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Widow, go you along. Lords, use her honourably.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Exeunt all but GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ay, Edward will use women honourably.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Would he were wasted, marrow, bones and all,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That from his loins no hopeful branch may spring,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To cross me from the golden time I look for!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And yet, between my soul's desire and me--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The lustful Edward's title buried--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Is Clarence, Henry, and his son young Edward,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And all the unlook'd for issue of their bodies,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To take their rooms, ere I can place myself:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: A cold premeditation for my purpose!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Why, then, I do but dream on sovereignty;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Like one that stands upon a promontory,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And spies a far-off shore where he would tread,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Wishing his foot were equal with his eye,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And chides the sea that sunders him from thence,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Saying, he'll lade it dry to have his way:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: So do I wish the crown, being so far off;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And so I chide the means that keeps me from it;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And so I say, I'll cut the causes off,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Flattering me with impossibilities.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My eye's too quick, my heart o'erweens too much,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Unless my hand and strength could equal them.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Well, say there is no kingdom then for Richard;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What other pleasure can the world afford?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I'll make my heaven in a lady's lap,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And deck my body in gay ornaments,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And witch sweet ladies with my words and looks.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: O miserable thought! and more unlikely

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Than to accomplish twenty golden crowns!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Why, love forswore me in my  mother's womb:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And, for I should not deal in her soft laws,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: She did corrupt frail nature with some bribe,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To shrink mine arm up like a wither'd shrub;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To make an envious mountain on my back,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Where sits deformity to mock my body;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To shape my legs of an unequal size;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To disproportion me in every part,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Like to a chaos, or an unlick'd bear-whelp

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That carries no impression like the dam.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And am I then a man to be beloved?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: O monstrous fault, to harbour such a thought!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Then, since this earth affords no joy to me,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But to command, to cheque, to o'erbear such

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As are of better person than myself,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I'll make my heaven to dream upon the crown,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And, whiles I live, to account this world but hell,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Until my mis-shaped trunk that bears this head

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Be round impaled with a glorious crown.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And yet I know not how to get the crown,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For many lives stand between me and home:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And I,--like one lost in a thorny wood,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That rends the thorns and is rent with the thorns,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Seeking a way and straying from the way;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Not knowing how to find the open air,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But toiling desperately to find it out,--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Torment myself to catch the English crown:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And from that torment I will free myself,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Or hew my way out with a bloody axe.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Why, I can smile, and murder whiles I smile,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And cry 'Content' to that which grieves my heart,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And wet my cheeks with artificial tears,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And frame my face to all occasions.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I'll drown more sailors than the mermaid shall;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I'll slay more gazers than the basilisk;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I'll play the orator as well as Nestor,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Deceive more slily than Ulysses could,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And, like a Sinon, take another Troy.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I can add colours to the chameleon,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Change shapes with Proteus for advantages,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And set the murderous Machiavel to school.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Can I do this, and cannot get a crown?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Tut, were it farther off, I'll pluck it down.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exit
